content.webTitle: Taj Mahal may host moonlit visits again

fields.headline: Taj Mahal may host moonlit visits again
fields.bodyText: The government of Uttar Pradesh state in northern India may allow tourists to visit the Taj Mahal by moonlight from later this year, easing a 20-year ban imposed to protect the monument, according to a report yesterday. "Our proposal is to keep the Taj Mahal open for five nights a month, on the full-moon day and two days preceding and succeeding the full moon," the United News of India news agency quoted Alok Sinha, a tourism official, as saying. If the 17th century monument in the city of Agra were to open every night of the year, it would have to be floodlit, according to Mr Sinha. But artificial lighting is not permitted because it could damage the monument or attract insects which could lay eggs on its white marble, UNI quoted Mr Sinha as saying. The Taj Mahal was built by the emperor Shah Jahan as a tomb for his favourite wife, Mumtaz Mahal. Tourists have been prohibited from visiting it at night since 1984, when India was battling militant Sikhs and feared an attack on the monument.
